occurrences.text: I mentioned last week, would be in the Lord, that no longer would she be focused upon this conflict with Rachel, and what a joy and what a blessing. But we find that Rachel begins to implement some really worldly, carnal behavior because she sees that she has no children. And seeing that she has no children, we find that she goes through these extents of being able to have children legally and handmade, and we find that this competition and this depth of carnality had a great impact upon Leah. And I'm kind of reviewing these things very quickly because it's interesting when we left off with Leah at son number 8 in verse number 13 of Genesis 30, I want you to notice what Leah says, and the contrast between son number 4, Judah, and son number 8, Asher. In verse number 13 of Genesis 30, it says, and Leah said, happy am I, for the daughters will call me blessed, and she called his name Asher. We mentioned that the name Judah means praise, and she says, now will I praise the Lord, acknowledging Jehovah, and here after the carnality that Rachel employs, and after all that takes place with this fleshly living, and Leah operating in like fashion, now she can only name her son happy. She says, happy am I, and notice what it is that would bring her a level of happiness. She says, for the daughters will call me blessed.

occurrences.text: was at a high point in verse number 35. In Rachel, she employed fleshly, carnal methodology, and Leah responded in like fashion. She goes from that pinnacle of spirituality, if you will, in verse 35, to a place of just slinging mud and competing with her sister. And that's tragic. As we continue through the text of Scripture, we come to verse number 18 and we see son number 9, and notice the Bible says in verse 17 of Genesis 30, it says, And God hearkened unto Leah, and she conceived and bare Jacob the fifth son. And Leah said, God hath given me my hire, because I have given my maiden to my husband, and she called his name Issachar. We find that here in verse number 18, we see son number 9, and his name Issachar means there is recompense or there is reward. I will say this for sake of the audience this evening, verses 14 through 17 I'm not going to read publicly this evening, but I want you to understand that the circumstances surrounding the birth of Issachar are unfortunate to say the least. And when you see what happens between Leah and Rachel in those verses of Scripture, and you see how Reuben the firstborn was used and how Jacob comes back and all of the carnality, it's really a sad situation. And here as she names him Issachar, there is recompense or there is reward.

occurrences.text: found that in chapter number 29, the Bible taught us that she was barren and she longed to have children. And I think there's a great problem here where she was envying her sister. We mentioned that last week and how terrible envy is and we ought not be envious. We ought not have envy in our lives and we understand that that was her position at the beginning of the chapter. But as we come to the latter part here of Genesis chapter number 30 and looking at the birth of Joseph, we see that the Bible tells us that God remembered her, hearkened to her and had opened her womb. And the reality is that that envy that she had at the beginning of chapter 30 led to great strife. It led to just carnality and fleshly living. And if we're not careful, envy in our lives will result in the same type of behavior. I understand that the circumstances will be quite different than what they are here in Genesis 29 and 30. But it's amazing to me how there's this, when there's envy, there's this desire for vain glory. There's this desire for attention. There's this desire. And you see that between Rachel and Leah and I believe that it's so imperative that we can make that application in our lives.
